commits.commitMessage:
Workaround limitation in non-blocking connect.

If a socket is in non-blocking mode, Qualcomm's connect() will return
EINPROGRESS.  However select() on such a socket does not properly
wake when the socket becomes connected, leaving no good way to wait
for the connection to complete.  A previous workaround for this issue
was put in place for LE-14580, but it seems it is not reliable, with
recent changes breaking this workaround for no apparent reason.

Instead, when connect returns EINPROGRESS, note the socket is still
connecting and poll until it has connected inside the event loop.
This effectively moves the workaround for LE-14580 into the event
loop, which allows other events on this thread to fire.

Related: LE-14580
Resolves: LE-16591
Change-Id: I613e093643394a956b6f5435ce30491e6bacb09d
commits.subject: Workaround limitation in non-blocking connect.

commits.commitMessage:
Restart QAPI timer if Legato timer has not expired

In some cases it has been observed that a QAPI timer may expire "early"
relative to the clock we are using as a timebase.  In this case,
recalculate the time until the timer should expire and restart the
QAPI timer.

Resolves: LE-16554
Change-Id: I29529626ebc350ac4f378ed874e4fe049e8961a9
commits.subject: Restart QAPI timer if Legato timer has not expired

comments.message: OK, got it, the order of the parameters are swapped.
why OS timer and the wakeup time are different?

OS timer is based on an internal hardware tiemr to that subsystem which we don't have access to.  Instead our wakeup times are often based on uptime which may fall slightly out of sync.

I've asked Qualcomm if there's a way to get a time which is synchronized with the timers, but have so far not received a useful response.

Do we expect the time to be substantial... or a matter of milliseconds?
If it is usually close, then I wonder if we could approximate and find the nearest timer that was close to expiring?

Should probably log / count these situations that occurred, for our own debugging.

I expect to be milliseconds or less.  I don't know what you mean by "finding the nearest timer" though.  There are only two OS timers per thread -- one for all deferrable timers, one for all non-deferrable timers.

Logging added.

I thought we had a chain (list) of timers that we manage, and a single system timer that fires. When we get the post sem, with your added code, we now know it is because of the system timer expiring (so we know for sure that there *should* be at least one timer expiring), so if we don't match any expired timers we know it is because of this drift of the values being compared. So, select the closest timer? We do know a timer should have fired.

Rescheduling adds a little complexity (reissuing a new timer)... and with the context switches if the timer differences are milliseconds then it's probably going to be more accurate if we take the closest timer the first time around.

Just a thought, I'm okay with rescheduling a timer (but I bet the accuracy will be worse ;) ).

Wouldn't be closest timer which is expired, it would always be first, because we sort by expiry time.  This solution is more general, and doesn't run into issues if timer callback doesn't expect to be called before timer "should" have expired.

commits.commitMessage:
Add tracing for timer triggers.

Add logs when a timer is triggered, and when timer is detected
on thread where timer function will be called.  This is to help
differentiate case where timer is never triggered, from bug
happens to prevent timer from being run.

Change-Id: Ic21c06c32aafab5be0e81d5754104ff23e1f0105
commits.subject: Add tracing for timer triggers.

commits.commitMessage:
Add le_fd_Lseek wrapper function on ThreadX

Add a compatibility function for the POSIX lseek() function on
ThreadX.  This is needed for ATSWI-380 workaround.

Resolves: ATSWI-394
Change-Id: If2a5888fe41196e115f55744cff3c8558ceda6b5
commits.subject: Add le_fd_Lseek wrapper function on ThreadX

comments.message:
the qapi function qapi_FS_Seek() has following returned values:

 *  @return  Returns QAPI_OK on success and -ve error code is returned on failure.
 *  - QAPI_ERR_EINVAL -- Invalid operation.
 *  - QAPI_ERR_EBADF -- File descriptor was not found.
 *  - QAPI_ERR_ESPIPE -- Some file descriptors (like pipes and FIFOs) are not seekable.

So, why don't we also handle QAPI_ERR_EINVAL and QAPI_ERR_ESPIPE here as well?

ESPIPE: we don't use Qualcomm pipes at all, so this error case should never be returned.
EINVAL: could add this; but it's also covered by the default statement below so not necessary.

commits.commitMessage:
Enable support for server name indication (SNI) in SSL/TLS

Description:
SNI not possible with TCP/HTTP in secure mode

Root Cause:
The macro MBEDTLS_SSL_SERVER_NAME_INDICATION is not enable in mbedtls_port.h

Solution:
Enable macro MBEDTLS_SSL_SERVER_NAME_INDICATION

Resolves: LE-16532
Related: MOLRC9X07-315 MOLRC9X07-321
Change-Id: I9ca62ffa5d2b1938858b095ed34cf6306b03c9d8
commits.subject: Enable support for server name indication (SNI) in SSL/TLS

commits.commitMessage:
Fix memory leak when stopping monitoring FD

When sending the SOCKMON_REMOVE message, a reference is added to the
fdMonitor when it is added command structure when sending it to the
socket monitor thread, but that reference is never released.  Release
the reference when the command is processed.

This issue does not occur with SOCKMON_ADD because the command
structure is added to the hashmap, and the fdMonitor reference
is released when the structure is removed from the hashmap.

Resolves: ATSWI-270
Change-Id: I4e3ea9b44df979f76f9306f0ee1bfa3bbf3156e5
commits.subject: Fix memory leak when stopping monitoring FD

commits.commitMessage:
Increase pthread keys while enabling configTree

When we enable configTree in RC76, we also increase the number of
pthread keys needed.

We have to increase the number of pthread keys, so the IPC mechanism
will not run out of available pthread keys.

Resolves: LE-16293
Related: QTI9X07TX-3531
Change-Id: I4f10ca575243afc7690fa8b70aeab7e03edb8273
commits.subject: Increase pthread keys while enabling configTree

commits.commitMessage:
Enhanced QAPIs for 32 sessions concurrent connection

The original qapi_select only supports up to 16 socket FDs, causing the not detecting POLLIN event on some sessions when more than 16 session connections are set up.
This patch is to implement the new enhanced QAPIs and replace the old APIs with the new v2 APIs in socketMonitor.
New enhanced APIs are listed bellow:
	1. qapi_select_v2
	2. qapi_fd_zero_v2
	3. qapi_fd_clr_v2
	4. qapi_fd_set_v2
	5. qapi_fd_isset_v2

Resolves: LE-15668
Signed-off-by: Jocelyn Ko <jko@sierrawireless.com>
Change-Id: I39eac8ff237ccd21185844fd6b937e495b1fa634
(cherry picked from commit 810f49039fbe07d331539b35c8c72961fd7932e9)
commits.subject: Enhanced QAPIs for 32 sessions concurrent connection

comments.message:
Is there any situation we would _not_ want to use the enhanced functions?  

Unless necessary, I would not create a config and just instead just switch to the new functions.

Hi Keith,

According to the Qualcomm comments attached below, only MDM9607 module supports v2 functions, that is why we create a config for the change instead of replacing the old functions. 

CR 2678655 is created for this fd_set changes, along with these changes, we also incorporated changes for support on no.of socket to 150. So, on MDM9607 target, by having CR 2678655 changes, no.of sockets supported to 150 + fd_set is also supported.

CR 2628630 with configuration parameter for supporting a max 74 sockets will be ported only to MDM9205.TX5.0.

In summary, for MDM9607, you need to have CR 2678655 for 150 sockets + fd_set for 150 sockets.
For MDM9205, you need to have CR 2628630 for supporting 74 sockets as it is memory constrained.
RC51 project has been canceled, so we only need to consider MDM9607 target in this code.

Hi Keith,

Thanks for the confirmation, so I'll use the V2 functions directly.

Here definitely should just be "select".  The qapi_socket_adaptor.c should hide internal Qualcomm details like which select function we are using, and expose an interface to other components like POSIX select().

Hi Keith,

If required, I'll change the relevant code after the discussion on qapi_socket_adaptor.h.

Hi Keith,

I have another concern is that a component using select_v2 requires bigger stack size (In this patch, 10240 is allocated for socketMonitor) to avoid modem reboot. If we replace original select with select_v2, it may have some impact on other callers.

That's very unfortunate.  In that case creating a select_v2() is OK, but it should always be defined, not depend on some #ifdef, so the developer can select the appropriate one for their situation.

Can you also add to the comment on select() that it can only be used with less than 16 FDs?
Just one comment, but otherwise looking good to me.
LE_CONFIG_RTOS is not needed here, as this code will only ever be compiled on RTOS.

commits.commitMessage:
Use IoT Keystore to handle PSK

Resolves: LE-14648
Change-Id: I96c01f861d9354c49cebfe34a2805c885daa8f03
commits.subject: Use IoT Keystore to handle PSK

comments.message: We need a compilation option for this in the .sdef.  E.g. IoT keystore should not be brought into rc51 20.06 release.

Suggest something like

    #ifdef MK_CONFIG_IOT_KEY_STORE
    #  define MBEDTLS_IOT_KEY_STORE_ENABLED
    #endif

or remove this flag from here, and add something like

    cflags:
    {
        #if ${MK_CONFIG_IOT_KEY_STORE_ENABLED} = 1
        -DMBEDTLS_IOT_KEY_STORE_ENABLED
        #endif
     }

to targets/threadx.sinc, or other appropriate spot.

Or even just document to smartsim team to enable they should add
    
    cflags:
    {
        -DMBEDTLS_IOT_KEY_STORE_ENABLED
    }

to gill.sdef to enable these features.
It might be nice to have a #ifdef/#error combination somewhere to enforce this.

commits.commitMessage:
Add endianness swap functions

Add endianness change function so new le_pack functions are compiled.

Resolves: LE-15245
Change-Id: I1ddfd0b01b517e59f5ed15ffc0a9ff1d8199230b
commits.subject: Add endianness swap functions

comments.message: no it's not, it's the TODO.
Okay, but it seems broken without an implementation here.

Yeah if someone ever started using these on rc76 it's gonna take a while before noticing the implementation is blank,
I'm gonna see if I can implement them for arm compiler.
I wonder if there's any other way to throw an error, not a compile error obviously.
Please do not try submitting such non-working code to ThreadX.  Especially since htonl() etc. already exist in qapi_socket_adaptor.h which you can use.
Great, didn't know they already exist.

Do you need these?  Using htons/ntohs() is right for htobe16(), but using it for bswap16() depends on the host order being little endian.  I think it would be better to either (1) skip implementing bswap() functions entirely, and implement htobe/betoh functions in terms of ntoh/hton functions directly, or (2) refactor so byte swapping code is placed in bswap() functions, and both hton and htobe functions are implemented in terms of bswap.
I'll do (2) but ultimately host order being little endian is still an assumption for this file and the other

True, but I'd like to isolate that to as few locations as possible.  Ideally    we should have:

1. Functions which always swap byte order
2. One set of functions which does host-to-specific byte order (e.g. htobeX, htoleX functions) implemented in terms of (1)
3. Any other function which does host-to-specific byte order implemented as a call to (2).

This way if we need to port to a BE platform, changes are restricted to layer (2).
Shouldn't these shifts match the shifts below?  I.e. last right shift should shift by 8 bits.
You just do things like this to punish my OCD, don't you?  Why are half of these upper-case F's and half lower-case?
lol, I'll fix that in the next patchset ;)

Move priority mapping logic to frameworkAdaptor

Also restores the thread priority mapping logic to be the same as
20.03 branches.

Resolves: LE-14916
Change-Id: I341f413d53e3ab121e07d149eedbb7bdf17c5904
commits.subject: Move priority mapping logic to frameworkAdaptor

comments.message: I think the priority mapping behaviour for ThreadX in 20.03 was different.  This was changed in master to maintain compatibiliy with other Legato products -- but if priority mapping is now per-product I think the 20.03 behaivour should be restored.
This was the original behaviour on FreeRTOS too, but it had the effect of "flattening" any manually configured priorities in the .adefs, if someone used "low," "medium," or "high."

Patch Set 1:

Hi Vincent,

Before confirming that this patch can resolve the current issue, we need to re-test LE-14612 and make sure we do not have regression. To test LE-14612, you need to send AT commands to the module with extremely high frequency (basically in a busy loop), and see if the module will crash. If the module can survive for 10 minutes, then we're pretty confident that we don't have LE-14612 regression.

For example, you can use the following AT commands to setup the module first:

AT+KCNXCFG=1,"GPRS","sp.telus.com",,,"IPV4",,,
AT+KHTTPCFG=1,"httpbin.org"

And then keep sending the following AT+KHTTPHEAD command:

AT+KHTTPHEAD=1,"/"

Thanks,
Tom

Patch Set 1:

This patchset 1 cannot pass the stress test for AT+HTTPHEAD: if continuously sending this AT command for about one hour, the device will be in a strange mode that is not able to connect to AT port, and Windows Device Manager won't refresh the list, only restart Windows can fix the issue.

So, please comment if you suspect some weird thing in this patch.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix the bug that data mode pipe closes before flushing data out

Previously, the data mode pipe can be closed even if it has data
pending processing. This will cause some problems such as some
messages will not be sent successfully to the at port. So this
patch adds a semaphore-based mechanism to make sure data pipe will
close after its data flush out.

Resolves: ATSWI-123 ATSWI-130
Change-Id: Ie3a740864a601290111c28fd84ee5ab7e09fd914
commits.subject: Fix the bug that data mode pipe closes before flushing data out

comments.message: We can change the wording here so that we don't need to repeat the logic in the comment.

Hi Keith, does your EOF mean there's no item in the pipe, i.e., "if (count == 0)"? if yes, I think currently the only way to know the item count of the pipe is le_sem_GetValue(DataPipeDevice->c2sCntSem), but I might be wrong.

Sorry, just got your idea that count is a variable in this function  but this condition "count==0" still cannot be used instead of "le_sem_GetValue(DataPipeDevice->c2sCntSem) == 0", one reason is in this function, after le_fd_Read()(line 465) and before le_sem_Post() (line 506), another thread (ATIP) could have another PipeWrite() which makes the pipe is no longer empty.

le_fd_Read() has identical signature and functioning to read() -- return values are:

> 0: read is a success, result is number of bytes read
== 0: other end of pipe is closed
< 0: error during read, error is contained in errno.

So count == 0 _always_ means the other end of the pipe is closed, and no more data will be available, ever.  If no data is available now, but pipe is still open so another pipe write could send more data, then either:

1) le_fd_Read() will block (if pipe is open in blocking mode), or
2) le_fd_Read() will return -1 with errno = EAGAIN or EWOULDBLOCK (if pipe is open in non-blocking mode).

So the situation you describe cannot happen.
Thanks Keith for the explanation, it makes sense. Let me verify and then update the patch.

Tested with "count==0" instead of "le_sem_GetValue(DataPipeDevice->c2sCntSem) == 0", which will block the the ClosePipe() waiting for the semaphore thus hangs the at port. After brief investigation, it is likely because "count==0" can be satisfied if a PULLIN event triggers this RxRawData() when the pipe is empty, but this cannot be satisfied in normal cases (e.g., ATSWI-123). Since in these cases, the RxRawData() will empty the pipe after le_fd_Read() and the count is > 0 at this situation.

POLLIN should be signalled again when the write side of the pipe is closed  See the ClosePipe function.  If that isn't working I think it's most likely a bug that needs to be fixed -- although check against a Linux test example first.

According to the implementation of fd_SignalDevice() for both ThreadX and HL78, if fd_GetPendingEvents() tells that POLLIN is not a pending event, then no actual POLLIN event callback will be called. Because of this, a call to fd_SignalDevice() in ClosePipe() won't fire RxRawData() and thus won't satisfy "count == 0" for posting the semaphore. If we do need to fire a callback of POLLIN i.e., RxRawData() even when pipe has no data to read, then the logic of PipeSelectScan() needs an update, and I think this will be another task/ticket since such modification will need a thorough test, and I don't think this is a correct way.

Can you create a simple test app on Linux to test what the behaviour of fdMonitor should be in this case?  RTOS must match.

We do not create new code to work around bugs in an underlying layer we control -- instead the underlying layer must be fixed.  Otherwise the code turns into a spiral of hacks and workaround.

For an example of how SelectScan() should work with a closed pipe, look at FifoSelectScan() -- if there are no writers, report POLLHUP if there's an item in the queue; and report POLLIN if there's an item in the queue.  In the case of a closed fifo (or pipe) this item will be the "FIFO closed" record.

Thanks Keith, I think the SelectScan() for pipe works similar as fifo on ThreadX based on the code if I am right. I also verified the following: 

* PipeSelectScan() cannot report PULLIN when ClosePipe() tries to signal a PULLIN, because the read lock cannot be taken due to the same time, PipeRead has taken the lock (because RxRawData() works in async mode, and it calls le_fd_Read() which takes the lock).

Currently, PipeRead() "ignores" the control message PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED in most cases (no POLLIN to return "count==0") if in a single read, there are other data items in one-reader pipe before this control message. While this logic is inconsistent for multi-reader cases, which will leave the control message to the top of the queue and eventually should trigger POLLIN and get "count==0". So a new patch updating the logic for one-reader data pipe to having the same logic, fixes this potential bug.
We don't need to repeat the logic in the comment.
If the purpose of this logic is to make FlushSemRef become zero, then I'd use le_sem_TryWait() so that we won't be blocked here accidentally.
I think this is not needed -- detect EOF in RxRawData instead (see my comment there).

Hi Keith, I think we will need this code for the case with following execution flow: 
1. RxRawData() finishes read and le_sem_Post(FlushSemRef) -> FlushSemRef > 0
2. A new PipeWrite pushing an item to the pipe -> FlushSemRef is still > 0 if without this code
3. A call to ClosePipe() will close the pipe because FlushSemRef > 0.
In step 3 of above case, ClosePipe() shall wait until the newly pushed data to be flushed out.
Only data pipe has this behavior. Maybe we can emphasize that it is a data pipe.
i.e. here do le_sem_Wait(ReadDoneSem) before switching to command mode?
Good point, I will test this suggestion.
It's [OUT], not [INOUT], since we never use its value in this function.

This is the most important modification in this patch. It ensures that when we close the pipe, the close event will trigger the PULLIN event handler, which can get the EOF (count == 0) message from le_fd_Read().
Why is this still needed?  It seems like ReadDoneRef should be cleared when closed, so should never be set at this point.  If it's set here, it's a bug.
Should just wait here?  I thought the whole point of the patch was to not switch into command mode before all data mode characters had been sent.

commits.commitMessage:
Correct inet_pton return values

The Qualcomm inet_pton() function has reversed return values
compared to what is specified in POSIX.  Provide a shim function
which converts the Qualcomm inet_pton() return into the standard
inet_pton() return values.

Resolves: LE-15337
Change-Id: I309e6e8ff51a77d0b2275d4f47478428fb92c241
commits.subject: Correct inet_pton return values

commits.commitMessage:
DRAFT: Use per-thread select() instead of socketMonitor thread

To avoid context switches between the socketMonitor thread and the
thread actually waiting for select, use a select() in each thread
as is done on HL78 and Linux instead of the socketMonitor thread.

This should increase download performance.

Change-Id: Ia2258514641af7ae63504c56ec6aa30b8531f710
commits.subject: DRAFT: Use per-thread select() instead of socketMonitor thread

commits.commitMessage:
Add support for merging hl78-maintenance.1 to master

Resolves: ATSWI-90
Change-Id: Id05477b6c4b869de1e9936fc2c7b1e4cf4f10629
commits.subject: Add support for merging hl78-maintenance.1 to master

comments.message: I don't like adding non-functional code.  Can the code in mbedTLS be disabled instead?
It seems can't be disabled unless modifying timing.c of mbedTLS.
It was not required previous to this merge.  What has changed?
Previously, I forgot to change few macro CONFIG_CUSTOM_OS to LE_CONFIG_RTOS, this causes some code which requires mbedTLS timing API not being built.
Is it necessary to enable debugging functions?  Memory is quite tight on some products (RC51).
Right, only one mbedTLS debug API was used, and I will disable it in next patch.

After investigation, found that enabling/#defining MBEDTLS_TIMING_ALT together with MBEDTLS_TIMING_C, will require implementations of following list of functions (actually these are all mbedTLS timing APIs in timing.c, and cannot choose one to implement, because once MBEDTLS_TIMING_C is #defined, all of the following timing APIs will be used in mbedTLS source code):
 * mbedtls_timing_get_timer()
 * mbedtls_timing_hardclock()
 * mbedtls_set_alarm()
 * mbedtls_set_delay()
 * mbedtls_get_delay()
However, we only need the first one, i.e., mbedtls_timing_get_timer(), and to implement mbedtls_set_alarm() will probably need alarm() which is not available on ThreadX platforms.

Thus, enabling MBEDTLS_TIMING_C and MBEDTLS_TIMING_ALT is not a solution for our case.
Is this smth we would have to be concerned about in HL78 for TLS connections?

Last review comment: use two macro and copying all of these functions and customize the mbedtls_set_alarm() to not use alarm().

Hi Mehdi: as long as HL78 has mbedtls_timing_get_timer() working properly, I don't think HL78 needs a change now. This comment is only for ThreadX.
I haven't seen the register keyword used in years -- did you copy this code?  Do we have a license?  Do you need to include a copyright notice?
Right, it was copied and I will rewrite this function in next patch.
double check the lsc and possibly copy with lsc notice
How did you come to select these values for the IPPROTO_TCP and IPPROTO_UDP defines?
I just picked some large enough values which don't conflict with existing socket options in qapi_socket.h on ThreadX.

So, keeping them the same as they were defined in include/qapi_netdb.h is not an option?

In other words, 

#define IPPROTO_TCP           1
#define IPPROTO_UDP           2

There are macros in qapi_socket.h on ThreadX:

#define     IP_OPTIONS          1      /**< For use with [gs]etsockopt() at IP_OPTIONS level. */
#define     IP_HDRINCL          2      /**< IP header is included with the data. */

So, I think it's better to avoid these values.
If these are already defined in a Qualcomm header we should include their definition instead.
Hi Keith, the macros IPPROTO_TCP and IPPROTO_UDP are not defined in Qualcomm header, I meant that values 1 and 2 are occupied by Qualcomm macros in their header.
Ok.  I was confused -- I thought qapi_netdb.h was a Qualcomm header when actually it's a Sierra header.  Makes sense now, thanks.
If level is IPPROTO_TCP or IPPROTO_UDP?  I don't think either are supported by Qualcomm.
Does anything need to be done here, or is it fine as-is?

I think this patch has definition for IPPROTO_UDP, an 

    || level == IPPROTO_UDP

should be added to this if statement.
I guess this is required as part of supporting the gettimeofday() function.   Correct?
No, this memmem() is actually required by httpserial.c.

I'm not seeing the corresponding calling code to memmem() in httpserial.c.    Can you please check that the patch which calls memmem() has been applied and is included in this merge.

Thanks.
There are five calls to memmem() in httpserial.c, please check httpserial.c in https://gerrit.legato/c/Legato/Apps/AtSwi/+/66359/-1..10 on lines 682, 686, 998, 1002, and 1258.
Yes, I see them in the original patch, but not in this merge patch.

I think the default view (Auto Merge) of the patch https://gerrit.legato/c/Legato/Apps/AtSwi/+/66359 only show the conflict part between master and uLegato, that's why it doesn't show the calls to memmem(). You may need to change Auto Merge to Parent 1/2 to see this part.
Yes, that was the problem!  Thanks Vincent

commits.commitMessage:
Replace le_fd_Create() with le_fd_Open()

A le_fd_Create() was added to support atomic file.  However the
prototype differed between ThreadX and Linux, and on ThreadX
(the only user), it was essentially the same as open().

So incorporate the functionality of le_fd_Create into le_fd_Open(),
and remove le_fd_Create().

Resolves: LE-14993
Change-Id: I034486c5e87586eba651ec967820ac151b45e902
commits.subject: Replace le_fd_Create() with le_fd_Open()

commits.commitMessage:
Add ability to set system time

Since Qualcomm does not currently provide a method of setting the
system time, this patch provides that ability. It's done by
providing an offset between the actual time, and what time was
set, so that it appears that the system time is what was initially
set via AVC.

Adds the following API's:

- clock_WriteTimeToMemory() - Writes the system time offset to
memory

- clock_UpdateTimeFromMemory() - Reads time offset from memory and
applies it to the current system time

- clock_EraseTimeOffset() - Sets the system time back to the
actual time by deleting the persistent offset

Resolves: LE-14875
Change-Id: I4e6244dd79c6d4e9a7df98aaf388bfc9212f5259
commits.subject: Add ability to set system time

commits.commitMessage:
Enable QXDM logging on RC51

LX QXDM IDs are still missing so this patch tags RC51 logs as legacy
so they will show up.

Also, multiple log levels are still not working so the ones that
aren't are prepeneded with the level of the log so they are
discernible

Change-Id: I5119c2e424bfd3a3bc7192da146ab15dc2edd38a
Resolves: LE-15132
commits.subject: Enable QXDM logging on RC51

comments.message: Should keep as is.  If you need debug logging, instead adjust through kconfig.  Eliminating debug was an important space saving measure.

You still enable it through KConfig and this shouldn't affect that behaviour. I'm modifying these because the debug and info QXDM levels for legacy aren't working on RC51 for some reason so I map them all to WARN and add the actual filter level before so that you can tell the difference between them.
I think Qualcomm has its own filtering -- maybe this filter level is set too high.
Need a Resolves:, which should appear before Change-Id:
Same comment as last patch; should leave this as-is.  Ditto below.

This looks like it multiply define LE_LOG_WARN to different values?  Shouldn't it have the same set of #define in both cases, but map to _LE_LOG_QLVL_LE_LOG_DEBUG, _LE_LOG_QLVL_LE_LOG_INFO to MSG_LEGACY_HIGH?
Whoops, you're right. I'll change this

This should be left.  Better to not timeout, even if we can recover now.

Patch Set 1:

> This should be left.  Better to not timeout, even if we can recover
 > now.
This workaround was added while we were waiting for Andrew Zhao to provide us with an implementation to change swi_datfwd_send() to blocking API. This is covered in QTI9X07TX-1941 and the following review:
https://gerrit.legato/#/c/external/qct/mdm9x07/+/62133/

The patches have been merged and I have verified that the module does not crash anymore while downloading and QXDM/QPST connection is okay as well.

In my opinion, we can remove this workaround.

comments.message:
As a note, I wonder if this could be changed to:

    le_fd_Open(const char *pathName, int flags, int mode)

I think on most platforms this would _work_ as long as mode wasn't actually accessed unless it was passed in by the caller, although some compilers might complain.

commits.commitMessage:
Enlarge mbedTLS heap space for two HTTPS sessions

Previously the heap space of mbedTLS is only large enough for one SSL
connection. That's why we cannot establish the second HTTPS session,
which requires the second SSL connection.

By increasing the size of mbedTLS heap space, now we can support two
HTTPS sessions.

Resolves: LE-14990
Change-Id: I00a1288fc6d05cb1aa5d19ee7d8e327c61a2a8a6
commits.subject: Enlarge mbedTLS heap space for two HTTPS sessions

commits.commitMessage:
The location can not be sync. to AVMS server

Issue Description:
When user request "Retrieve Data" for location. The value of some resources
of the location object are not synchronized on AVMS server.

Root cause:
The positioning service and related are disabled because of pa_gnss platform
adaptor does not be porting.

Solution:
Porting pa_gnss platform adaptor and enable positioning service and related.

Resolves: LE-14966

commits.commitMessage:
Properly cleanup resources when close pipe

A modem can only handle one AT command at a time. Therefore, when we
send an AT command to the modem, we should wait for the final response
and then send the next AT command.

However, in this ticket, we don't wait for the final response of the
running AT command: we keep sending AT commands until the system
crashes. Although this is not a normal behavior, it reveals bugs in
multiple components in the system. Pipe is one of the components that
causes this issue.

The problem in pipe is that when we switch from the Data Mode to the
Command Mode, we need to close the client-side of the pipe. However, we
didn't properly cleanup resources when we close the pipe, so that we may
access memory that has been freed, which causes the crash.

After properly cleanup resources when we close the pipe, and handle
read/write operations when the other end of the pipe is closed, no more
crashes when we keep sending AT commands. However, this patch can not
work alone. We also need the patches from the firmware side to make it
work.

Resolves: LE-14612
Change-Id: I6bd03308abfebbd35732a9292302a0f470b9dbc0
commits.subject: Properly cleanup resources when close pipe

comments.message:
After add this code,if server side fd is opened first followed by a synchronized BLOCKING call pipeRead(), it will hit LE_ASSERT(filePtr->flags & FNONBLOCK) and cause crash. 
Is this case expected behavior? I think it should return errno = EPIPE rather than crash.
When there's no remote writer, PipeRead should return 0 in both blocking mode and non-blocking mode. I will fix this issue at the bottom of this function.
we are still using the pipe without checking tx queue info, there is potential risk. like scenario L814

We don't need to check tx_queue_info_get() here, because le_sem_Wait(cntSem) on line 590 should guarantee that the tx queue is not empty. If the tx queue is empty here, then we should fix the logic of cntSem, which is the main purpose of this patch.

Why do we need this check ? 
For multi-readers case, if  *remoteWriters=0, the close message will be kept in tx_quere but cntSem is reset. Later if remoteWriter is opened again it will alway gets blocked in pipeWrite() because the close message item is not able to read by reader side.
No need to push a closed message. Just need trigger a POLLHUP event.
The purpose of the close message is to wake up other blocked readers to check remote writers and take appropriate actions.
OK, but please add "fd_SignalDevice(&deviceObjPtr->deviceObj, POLLIN)" Here as we discussed.
there is possibility that remote reader closed but local side still write the message to remot reader side, so we had better add the code to clean the message during pipe open
These code should be put in old place(after tx_queue_send()).

This change is proposed by Vincent, and I think it makes sense to check whether there are remote readers at the beginning. I've checked the pipe implementation of Linux kernel, and it also checks whether there's any reader at the beginning.

May I know why you think this logic should be in the original place?
put these code to original place, then there is a possiblity a PULLIN message sent to remot side but the message already removed.
As we discussed ,both Vincent and I think it's better to put into original place (after tx_queue_send()).

I think it's better use mutex to protect this code and le_sem_post.
in case tx_queue_send is called then cpu is switched to the remote side, and remote side is closing the pipe. the result will be that remote side drop all the message and consume all the semaphore.
but after the cpu is switched back, a further post at L821 will make the module dead.
Assuming that you agree to put if (*remoteReaders == 0) code block at the beginning, then we don't need to check again here.
seems that le_sem_GetValue(cntSem) > 0 already means POLLIN, so no need to do the further check
Please remove these code, cntSem > 0 always means POLLIN.

Hi Tom
better to put this line after 984, and change to le_sem_wait(), this will make messages in the queue alwasy equal to the semaphore post count. image the scenario:
1. tx_queue_send()
2. NOP
3. semaphore_post()
if high priority task preempted the cpu at step 2 to close the pipe, then when cpu is back to step3, one more post is sent out.
le_sem_Wait() will block forever when cntSem is 0, so I can't use it to cleanup cntSem.

the logic is:
always post a semaphore when send a message.
always wait a semaphore when receive a message.
then message count in the queue should be always equal to semaphore count. I think there should be no "le_sem_Wait() will block forever" scenario, otherwise there should be a bug somewhere.
don't understand this line? could you tell me what is the purpose?

Whenever we pass le_sem_Wait(cntSem), we have to make sure we pop up a queue item. We don't pop up queue item when we have multiple readers, so we have to increment cntSem, so that other readers can see the PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED message.
OK, I don't have comment on this part since we will not have multiple readers scenario.

better to change to else{}? since we have used Lock()/Unlock to protect pipeopen and pipeclose, I think it is impossible that *remoteReaders may change during tx_queue_send() in L823. please double check this part.?
their should be associated semaphore wait somewhere
That's why we need to call le_sem_TryWait(cntSem) below.
Here LE_FATAL_IF(le_sem_TryWait(cntSem) == LE_WOULD_BLOCK is missing after poping the close item.
We don't have to call le_sem_TryWait again here, because the previous le_sem_Wait already decrements cntSem.
OK. I forget this is after le_sem_TryWait().
Here "fd_SignalDevice(&deviceObjPtr->deviceObj, POLLIN);" is missing after post cntSem.

The purpose of calling le_sem_Post(cntSem) here is to increment cntSem. We don't need to call fd_SignalDevice() here because other readers already receive the POLLIN events, which were fired when we put the PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED message into the queue. All we need to do is putting cntSem back to its original value, which was decremented by the previous le_sem_Wait() call.

For multiple readers case of this logic, the close item is NEVER popped out, which will cause the writer always gets blocked in writting data to the pipe after open the pipe next time. It's also what I have seen in my previous tests.
Why remove "closed = true;" and add break?

Because "close = true" should be done when we process the PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED message. We call break here, because after the while loop, the logic will add POLLIN and call fd_SignalDevice(), so that readers will be able to handle this PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED message.
Discussed with Vincent, It seems we can remove these code which is impossible to execute.
I don't know why this logic is impossible to reach.

we think when "*remoteWriters == 0", it means remote side alread sent a PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED message, this will cause queueCtl->tx_queue_enqueued ==1.
secondly, it is not neccessary to add this code(if(xxx){}) since a PIPE_WRITE_CLOSED message will be handled by piperead() again when this functions returns.

from my test, there is a problem here, incase vsio is sending data very fast(s->c queue), it will finally be blcoked at L823. if at this moment, atIP is receving some data and trying to send it to at port(c->s queue), it will also be blocked at L820.
then atip has no chance to get message from queue.
the root cause is that s->c queue and c->s queue should not share the same lock/unlock mutex. we should seperate it.
This is cleaned up when we close the pipe.  If the close logic is not cleaning correctly, close logic should be fixed.  This also introduces a potential issue with multiple reader/writer.

Needs to be taken in PipeOpen() and Pipelose() as well when modifying number of readers.

BUT: I think there risks a deadlock here between PipeClose and writing to a full queue.  PipeClose() will need to take the write lock to update remoteReaders, but that will not be possible if pipe is blocking on write.  So it will not be possible to close the remote end of a full pipe -- hopfully this makes sense I will try to expand on this point by email.
PipeClose() doens't take the same write lock as the one in PipeWrite(), so the deadlock that you described will not happen.

Commit message style: Legato

Please check that the syntax of your ticket declaration(s) follows commit guidelines:

commits.commitMessage:
Add workaround to avoid timeout using KHTTPGET

When sending raw data to the AT port in data mode, while
swi_datfwd_send() returns LE_BUSY, replace sched_yield() with 90ms
sleep as a workaround to avoid HTTP timeout and crash caused by
watchdog reset.

Resolves: LE-14682
Change-Id: I6baa25d6fc337d980a4fe542adbd8939c28547f6
commits.subject: Add workaround to avoid timeout using KHTTPGET

comments.message: This is just a workaround solution. swi_datfwd_send() will not return LE_BUSY after changing to blocking API in QTI9X07TX-1941.

commits.commitMessage:
Support decoupling mbedtls from liblegato

- Allows time function to be called in legato from mbedtls_port
- Removes random number framework adaptor code from mbedtls_port.c
and puts it in it's own file, rand.c

Resolves: LE-14602
Change-Id: I1faa744bc8d11defd0414b96e06603b4f4f5cbd3
commits.subject: Support decoupling mbedtls from liblegato

comments.message: I think this file should be moved out of the FA and paired with mbedtls_port.c.
Where is this defined?  It's named like a static function, but it doesn't seem to be in this file.
It's defined in mbedtls_port.c. I've changed it to mbedtls_port_InitRandomGenerator()
Just remove, instead of adding commented-out.
I still feel that this header is located in the wrong place for what it is being used for now.  It should be in the same location as mbedtls_port.c.
Won't the functions in this file now end up being linked in twice, once for mbedtls and once as part of liblegato?

Yes, they will be. The alternative is that we copy and paste the code from clock_posix.c into mbedtls_port.c, which is what was done before. I hoped this change would make sure that we don't have two copies of the same code even though it's being built twice.

Or create a posix_compat library containing this and other posix compatibility functions.  Or add -L--undefined_and_export for each of the functions you want to export to threadx.sinc.  I think the second option is the best for now, that's what we're doing for fputc.
should this file be called something else? like gmtime_r.c?
It also includes the time function though
Should output to QXDM instead.  If LE_WARN/LE_ERROR are not available, this can use QAPI_MSG_SPRINTF() directly.

commits.commitMessage:
Add the max HTTP session count to KConfig

We need to allocate enough memory for the StoragePool memory pool, so
that we can create the maximum number of HTTP sessions at once.

In order to calculate the memory pool size, we add a new configuration
for the maximum HTTP session count, and derive the memory pool size from
it.

Resolves: LE-14685
Change-Id: Id97424ddc397e86183e4a01b9d5a94f12cbe4c96
commits.subject: Add the max HTTP session count to KConfig

commits.commitMessage:
[ThreadX] Fix TCP/UDP session failure problem

Modifications:
1) Refine the definition of struct sockaddr_storage to
   support both IPV4 and IPV6 address type properly.
2) Pass the exact address length based on address family
   type to socket related qapi functions.

Resolves: LE-14604 LE-14708
Change-Id: I5d4b199a9d4bd662a3a95fa567cf8f3f59628169
commits.subject: [ThreadX] Fix TCP/UDP session failure problem

Clean up warnings in frameworkAdaptor

As part of work to clean up warnings when log messages are disabled,
also clean up other warnings in the frameworkAdaptor.

Resolves: LE-14722

commits.commitMessage:
Optimize logging

The original method of eliminating log messages based on static log
level relied on the compiler optimizing out the log messages during
dead-code elimination.  For whatever reason this optimization fails
to completely eliminate all log messages on ThreadX platform.

Therefore an alternate method based on replacing logging macros with
empty macros will be used on ThreadX-based platforms.

Additionally, remove the ability to set the log cutoff level at
runtime.  This feature is unused on RTOS platforms.

Resolves: LE-14722
Change-Id: I443a82ff5cd87b7de081b9d1ec58c23221999460
commits.subject: Optimize logging

commits.commitMessage:
Enable mbedTLS PEM parsing feature

Recently we have a regression in the master branch, which makes HTTPS
not working. The problem is caused by mbedTLS failing to parse the root
certificate stored in the module.

The root cause of this issue is that we disabled many mbedTLS features
in order to minimize its memory usage on RC51. To resolve this issue, we
need to bring back some disabled features, so that mbedTLS knows how to
parse the root certificate.

Resolves: LE-14679
Change-Id: I55b07374c699be579c48f847241843cacda3a362
commits.subject: Enable mbedTLS PEM parsing feature

commits.commitMessage:
[ThreadX] Use le_pa_secStore from master branch

ThreadX is currently using an older version of le_pa_secStore(18.09).
ThreadX will use the le_pa_secStore on Master branch after this patch.

Highlighted Changes:
1) Replace all file stream related functions with file descriptor
   related functions.
2) Create Legato root directory if it does not exist.
3) Add fd_Open in fileDescriptor.c.

Resolves: LE-14079 LE-14274
Change-Id: I47ee91bc994e60c43acdea32f95919af49f97b54
commits.subject: [ThreadX] Use le_pa_secStore from master branch

comments.message: Naming here is not good.  Is there some way we can integrate this to le_fd?  I would like to converge on one filesystem abstraction layer, not add yet another one.
Can you remove these functions from this patch?  Should not add them just to remove again next patch.

So you suggest to remove this part from this patch, then I do not need to remove them from the patch https://gerrit.legato/c/Legato/frameworkAdaptor/threadx/+/60375 ?

Actually now all these patches are under the same topic and combined into one patch set. The patch does not work without any one in the patch set.
Naming?  Function is called IsReadOnly(), but it actually creates Legato root directory.

This function name is defined on Legato and used for Linux/ThreadX. It is used to check the /legato directory is writable or not. Since /legato on Linux is writable by default, here on ThreadX is aligned with Linux, and make it writable.

We need to write files under /legato, if no directory /legato, QAPI can not writable. So if no directory /legato available at that moment, we need to create one.

commits.commitMessage:
[ThreadX] Framework for adding file system operations to le_fd

This is a framework for registering a default handler to le_fd, so
if a device is not specifically declared for a file path, it will be
passed to the default handler.

Stubs for the default handler are included, which should be filled
in with an implementation that calls qapi_FS_ functions.

Resolves: LE-14079
Change-Id: Ic90d79bf72ea599d91a1fcb1613ea7ccd439a698
commits.subject: [ThreadX] Framework for adding file system operations to le_fd

comments.message: Should never hit this case, as here devicePtr should always equal EfsDefaultDevice.

Yes you are right. But I put here as a protection in case something wrong happens. And this does happen during my test.

For example, in code pipe.c

When we call le_fd_MkPipe, le_fd_Open is called first, then it goes into SearchDevice(), since it is the first time to call it (we try to create/make a pipe), the device is not in the list, according to our design, default device is assigned such as

    *deviceObjPtr = DefaultDevicePtr;

Now the piple is hooked with regular file function.

That is the reason I put this protection here.

Also I make the modification in pipe.c in this patch also.

But in that case this check still does not help, since deviceObjPtr will still be DefaultDevicePtr, and name will still be NULL.

If you want to put in a check, use LE_ASSERT() or LE_FATAL_IF() instead.  See: https://docs.legato.io/latest/ccodingStdsComplexity.html#codingComplexErrorHandling
Should not use malloc() in Legato.
Same comment as above -- should not use malloc() in Legato.
Don't need to check this -- this is guaranteed by EfsOpen()/EfsCreate.
This check is not needed as this is guaranteed by the framework.
Also not needed (this is guaranteed since EfsOpen and EfsCreate only return success if fd >= 0).
Why removing this logic here? It is necessary because like the comment said, we want to allow opening an existing pipe device in several places.

This part is not necessary. 

The function is called to make or create a pipe, so CreatePipe should be called first. If no pipe with the given device is created, then create one, and call le_fd_Open. If the pipe with the given device name has been created already, then errno = EEXIST is returned. So we need to check the errno returned from CreatePipe, If pipe exists already, we just need to call le_fd_Open.

I modify this part since I found this part causes some problem if it works on the frame work provided by Keith

I put the comments again here:

 For example, in code pipe.c

When we call le_fd_MkPipe, le_fd_Open is called first, then it goes into SearchDevice(), since it is the first time to call it (we try to create/make a pipe), the device is not in the list, according to our design, default device is assigned such as
    *deviceObjPtr = DefaultDevicePtr;

Now the piple is hooked with regular file function.

So later on the device actually is created as a regular file instead of pipe. But if we follow the modified logic, this problem is avoided.
Why removing the logic but keeping this comment?
Needs an underscore (see my other comment).

commits.commitMessage:
Fix repeated resets on RC51

A recent push inadvertently creates a new pipe. This patch changes
le_mem_AssertAlloc to just le_mem_Assert so that the device doesn't
automatically assert when it exceeds the number of pipes allowed

Resolves: LE-14694

commits.subject: Fix repeated resets on RC51

commits.commitMessage:
Remove "LEGATO | " prefix from logging strings

Each ThreadX logging message is prepended with LEGATO which is not
necessary anymore as legato messages have their own filter "LX".
By removing LEGATO prefix from logging messages, it can free up a
lot of space.

Resolves: LE-14654
Change-Id: Ic8d47345da7c10f7be5dbccccfd79f367275935b
commits.subject: Remove "LEGATO | " prefix from logging strings

commits.commitMessage:
[ThreadX] Fix TCP session failed to start on target for IPV6

Root Cause:
SOCK_ADDRESS_LENGTH on ThreadX is defined based on the size
of IPv4 type socket address.

Modifications:
1) Replace SOCK_ADDRESS_LENGTH with the size of struct
   sockaddr_storage.
2) Correct the padding size of struct sockaddr_storage

Resolves: LE-14604
Change-Id: Ia4bfef81bb7ae2bd221b3602cc9a829cc38c4274
commits.subject: [ThreadX] Fix TCP session failed to start on target for IPV6

comments.message: If your changing this to the size of sockaddr_storage, you can remove this line and comment above and replace all references to SOCK_ADDRESS_LENGTH to sizeof(struct sockaddr_storage). Also, remove it in atIpVars.h

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

(4 comments)

I got part way through, but I don't think this can be merged.  You are disabling significant parts of mbed TLS that are required for proper security.  In addition, we are working to remove tinydtls from the code base, so DTLS support will be required in mbed TLS.  I spent at least a couple of days researching and tuning these parameters when I did the original port.

The one class of features that I think are fine to switch are the ones that trade off performance for memory size.  There are also probably a few protocol related features that can be turned off.

commits.commitMessage:
Disable unnecessary mbetdls features

In an attempt to reduce memory, disable features in mbedtls that
aren't being used

Resolves: LE-14595
Change-Id: I6805b41addf5102ad6c5840abab0a581f7a66767
commits.subject: Disable unnecessary mbetdls features

comments.message: I think at least some of these cipher modes will need to stay enabled to support HTTPS properly.

Actually, I don't think any of these modes is needed for the cipher suites we want to support.  Additionally, CBC mode should be disabled as well.  We should only support authenticated encryption modes such as GCM, CCM, etc.

I strongly recommend disabling CBC cipher suites but that would mean a change in the AT Command interface so they should be done in concert.

We should also disable all ciphers (ie. Camellia) except for AES unless their is a specific regulatory need.

The list of approved cipher suites can be found in section 9.1.3 in https://confluence.sierrawireless.com/display/SEG/Approved+Cryptographic+Standards

Disabling this will make the ciphers harder to use properly.  Generally this sort of padding is a handful of bytes at the end of a message to make sure the block size is correct.  Without this, blocks of the exact size will have to be provided anyway, so there would be no noticable memory savings.
Since we will only support authenticated encryption modes GCM, CCM and possibly CHACHA20_POLY1305 padding is unnecessary.
This change adds the ARC4 ciphers back in, which is not what you want.
I'm not in favour of disabling these for security reasons.  Also, they are required for TLS 1.3 support.

I agree that the Edward curves 25519 and 448 should be enabled but some of the other curves probably don't need to be supported.  I would enable these:

#define MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP256R1_ENABLED
#define MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP384R1_ENABLED
#define MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_SECP521R1_ENABLED
#define MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_CURVE25519_ENABLED
#define MBEDTLS_ECP_DP_CURVE448_ENABLED

and disable the rest.
This would be very useful to have.
I strongly recommend removing all of the RSA based key exchange for d/tls but this will mean a change in the AT Command interface so they must be done in concert.
I strongly recommend removing all of the RSA based key exchange for d/tls but this will mean a change in the AT Command interface so they must be done in concert.
I think we should keep this one.
I think we should keep this one.

This should probably be disabled.  PKCS#1 v1.5 for encryption must not be used.  PKCS#1 v1.5 for signature generation should be deprecated.  However, PKCS#1 v1.5 for signature verification is OK and may be needed depending on the application.
This will likely be needed in the future.
One of MBEDTLS_HMAC_DRBG_C, MBEDTLS_CTR_DRBG_C is needed.  No real preference but we should make a consistent choice a stick with it.

I picked HMAC_DBRG when doing the original mbed TLS port for ThreadX because it seemed like it had the potential to be slightly more secure: https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2017/08/proof_that_hmac.html

Having said that, I have no problem with using CTR_DRBG for consistency.
Not sure if there's any existing code using hmac_drbg vs ctr_drbg on threadx platforms, but on the HL78 (freeRTOS) we use ctr_drbg.
I am not confident that you have this commented, what would happen to DTLS if we want to use it in HL78?
This file is only used by rc76 and rc51.
But we would need DTLS support in RC76 and RC51 too. Why is this file only used in certain modules?
Though not supporting it on RC51 would be a feature gap.  It would mean that you have different versions of atSwi, which is something we are trying to avoid.

@kwalton, this particular file is just to support the mbed TLS port to RC51/RC76.  On HL78, a customised mbed TLS library is included in Altair's code deliverable, and the accompanying porting is done there.  This meant I had to do a new port to bring it in to RC76, which is where this file came from.

@kwalton: My thought is just that since we are still in the bring-up phase of rc51, we shouldn't be enabling features just because we might need them in the future.  For DTLS in particular we will have two implementations if we enable this: mbedTLS DTLS (which we're not currently using), and tinyDTLS (which is used by LWM2M).  So I think a reasonable path is to disable mbedTLS DTLS for now.  If we need it later, also switch LWM2M to use mbedTLS DTLS instead of tinyDTLS.

But I'm OK with it being enabled if it doesn't kill memory consumption too much.

Is disabling these DTLS options needed if we're disabling DTLS entirely?  My concern is there have been some rumblings of using mbedtls instead of our current tinyDTLS -- if we switch, we will presumably need to re-enable all (or most) of these again as there are security implications.

This needs to be uncommented, see: https://tls.mbed.org/kb/how-to/dtls-tutorial 
In HL78xx, we are going to implement DTLS feature.

This also might need to be uncommented; we might need to use it in our DTLS implementation for HL78xx.
For reference see: https://tls.mbed.org/kb/how-to/dtls-tutorial

This needs to be uncommented, we will need to use in our DTLS implementation for HL78xx.
For reference see: https://tls.mbed.org/kb/how-to/dtls-tutorial
So we are trading off footprint for power consumption. For LPWA modules, I'm not sure we want to do this?

I strongly recommend removing all of the RSA based key exchange for d/tls but this will mean a change in the AT Command interface so they must be done in concert.  So if we are not prepared to remove this yet, it can be be left for the future but I noticed that CBC mode was disabled so I'm not sure what stage we are in at the moment.
I interpreted a previous comment wrong so I reenabled CBC. I don't think we're prepared to remove it yet
Since CBC is now enable PKCS7 padding should be enabled as well.

commits.commitMessage:
Port le_atomFile to RC76

Implement the basic le_atomFile_Open/Create/Cancel/Close/Delete functions.
Lock files will not be supported, so the atomic file will not guarantee
exclusive access on RC76.

Highlighted Changes:
1) The mode returned from QAPI stat is compatible with POSIX enum type,
   but a different QAPI enum type is used with QAPI create with mode,
   so a mapping is added.
2) For functions to call efs functions directly, POSIX enum type should
   be used instead of QAPI enum type.
3) To unlink or rename files, all related files should be closed first.
   It is the requirement in QAPI documentation.

Resolves: LE-13790
Change-Id: I976eb0f492096160a511e91aaf8cdb555fa5445b
commits.subject: Port le_atomFile to RC76

comments.message:
Bracket the macro and all macro parameters please.

Or just write an inline function instead.
Please use le_mem_Alloc in new code.

If I interpret this correctly, for an input file path of "/my/file.txt" this will produce an output path of "/tmp/...my.file.txt.bak~~XXXXXX".  If I also have an input path of "/my.file.txt" it will give the same output path, despite having a different input path.  The ".bak~~XXXXXX" pattern is a holdover from Linux, where the XXXXXX is replaced with a unique identifier to avoid these sorts of conflicts.  I think the same sort of mechanism is required here, where a unique identifier is produced and used as part of the temporary file name.
I implemented the method as we discussed in the update patch.
You can't do this.  strtok modifies originFilePath, but this has been declared as const.

My test shows originalFilePath is not modified by strtok.
Introdueced a new string variable and let strtok work on this new variable.
Thanks Keith.
strtok_r is kind of overkill here, really you just need to iterate over the string and increment count each time you see a '.'
This should be a statically allocated pool.
This will be the size of the pointer, not the size of the string.

commits.subject: Replace LE_NOT_POSSIBLE with the more appropriate error code

comments.message: Should not change return values which are not LE_NOT_POSSIBLE.
Suggested to use LE_NOT_PERMITTED or LE_UNSUPPORTED. Need to replaced the case FsPrefixPtr == NULL to LE_UNAVAILABLE to use LE_UNSUPPORTED for read-only FS.

We need to reach a consensus here & keep moving forward. This fs.c exists also at freamwork/liblegato/linux/fs.c. 
Keith's original suggestion came from: 
https://gerrit.legato/#/c/Legato/+/57329/2/framework/liblegato/linux/fs.c
Do we need this code to return the same le_result_t for both Linux & ThreadX?
Please consent & resolve this soon.

Actually my original comment for this change is https://gerrit.legato/c/Legato/frameworkAdaptor/threadx/+/57339#message-e26cde6d466cceb3474267b9b620c38daf489ac2.

Note was that LE_UNAVAILALBE is not suitable as it indicates a temporary error condition, whereas this error is permanent.  Using LE_UNAVAILABLE here instead of on line 126 does nothing to resolve that comment -- LE_UNAVAILABLE is equally unsuitable here as on line 126.

Values other than LE_NOT_POSSIBLE MUST NOT be changed by this patch.  Since LE_UNSUPPORTED is also used, I'll repeat my original suggestion that LE_NOT_PERMITTED is probably the best match for the error condition on line 126.
Thanks Keith for your review. I already updated.

commits.commitMessage:
Connect to invalid TCP server error

Issue Description:
KTCP_IND would return when set up invalid ip/port for TCP connection
This ticket is cloned by QTI9X07TX-1144

Root Cause:
Connection result is not caught when TCP connection is in-progress.

Solution:
Use qapi_getpeername to get peer address to decide whether the connection is established.

Resolves: LE-14156
Change-Id: I18fedd7728e99751edec0e2a8fc6c7602b120cdc
Signed-off-by: jocelyn <jko@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: Connect to invalid TCP server error

commits.commitMessage:
Wait for notification fd has been removed.

When monitoring/unmonitoring an FD, wait for notification from the
socketMonitor thread that the fd has been added and/or removed.  This
works around an memory corruption issue which can occur on socket
close.

Resolves: LE-14510
Change-Id: I31873dbec8619e91ddc27324f34a2a16e45ed28f
commits.subject: Wait for notification fd has been removed.

comments.message:
Isn't it more natural to have the if (ret < 0) type check?
Also it does LE_WARN_IF(errno != EAGAIN && errno != EWOULDBLOCK) in the ReceiveSocketMonitorCommand, not FATAL. Wouldn't this be the same?

If we fail to receive, there is a recovery, we can retry receive.  If we fail to send, there is no recovery as we don't unblock whomever sent the socket monitor command, leaving that thread deadlocked.

I generally prefer

    ret < 0

form for tests as well, however here I felt that

    function(with lots and lots of arguments) < 0

pushed the test away from the context in which the test was being performed and was more confusing.

Found this LE_FATAL_IF() being hit after investigating ram dump and Qualcomm's Diag report for LE-14479:

20:29:21.543:                           time.c:691      heap profile data total_bytes = 10117120 used_bytes = 3015545 heap_used_bytes = 3131672 free_memory_bytes = 6985448 max_used = 3028393  max_request = 404000
20:29:21.543:                        VAdcLog.c:110      VADC conv req: index 6
20:29:21.545:                                 :346      Failed to create command socket
No comment about the missing close()?

Patch Set 1:

Needs to be tested and documentation needs to be modified to reflect new behaviour.

commits.commitMessage:
Stop sending raw data when ATIP app fails

When the AT command handler fails, it will stop reading the pipe and
switch back to the Command Mode. However, the firmware doesn't know that
the AT command handler will stop reading the pipe, so it keeps pushing
raw data to the pipe, which operates in the blocking mode. When one end
stops reading and the other end keeps writing, the pipe will ultimately
be blocked, which will trigger watchdog timer and close the AT port
device.

To resolve this issue, we just need to stop the firmware from keeping
sending raw data by deregistering the data forward callback before
switching to the Command Mode. Since the callback is deregistered in the
Command Mode, we need to remember register the callback before switching
to the Data Mode.

Resolves: LE-14143
Change-Id: I5a4351ac919ee9a4b8396091e224e6f105517ce1
commits.subject: Stop sending raw data when ATIP app fails

comments.message: Do we need to flush the pipe in OpenPipe() like what we do in ClosePipe() to ensure no obsolete data exists after OpenPipe()?

I don't think we need to. In the PipeWrite function, line 787, there is another code snippet that tries to flush the pipe when there's no reader, which should be able to handle the situation that you mentioned.

commits.commitMessage:
Support mutiple AT ports in DataPipe

Previously we only supported USB AT port, because we didn't know how to
identify where AT commands are coming from.

Now we've learned that we can identify the source of an AT command from
the ATFWD callback function, so we removed the hard-coded AT port
constant and added firmware APIs to support multiple AT ports.

Resolves: LE-13956
Change-Id: Ic35ea50c8243ec9534b26646e1dba3e6d8639d76
commits.subject: Support mutiple AT ports in DataPipe

This is in frameworkAdaptor, so it's not too bad.  LE-13904 exists to rework this code.
Oops.  Too many repos with contents that have similar names.  I keep forgetting where I am.

comments.message: Is this required? Won't calling le_sls_RemoveAfter() at the head of the list do the same thing as le_sls_Pop()?

No, the API doc (https://docs.legato.io/latest/le__singlyLinkedList_8h.html#a85f5132147870e260b3b142665ec587e) says le_sls_RemoveAfter() removes the node after the given one, so the head needs to be handled differently.
If you pass NULL as the node argument (2nd argument) for le_sls_RemoveAfter() it will remove the first element (despite the documentation).

commits.commitMessage:
Replace strerror() and strerror_r() with LE_ERRNO_TXT()

strerror() and strerror_r() have different behaviour and different
prototypes depending on the system.  So replace these with a new
function LE_ERRNO_TXT() which will behave like strerror() but is
thread safe.

Resolves: LE-14026
Change-Id: I2b6a0c91be40eed3b33a7ec029e8bf396d868033
commits.subject: Replace strerror() and strerror_r() with LE_ERRNO_TXT()

commits.commitMessage:
Check invalid file descriptors

Previously we didn't check invalid file descriptors (<0), which may
cause strange behavior that is hard to debug.

Now we check invalid file descriptors in fd_IsCustomFile, which is
called by other le_fd functions, so we can ensure that we will no longer
process invalid file descriptors.

Resolves: LE-13697
Change-Id: Id19d3afee1f3ee1af27091af29134c94ab565ede
commits.subject: Check invalid file descriptors

commits.commitMessage:
Fire POLLIN event for FIFO corner case

Previously, if a thread would blocking-write to a FIFO-based file
descriptor greater than what the FIFO can hold, it could fail to
trigger a POLLIN event. This would  block until something was read,
which wouldn't happen because the POLLIN event wasn't fired resulting
in a deadlock.

Resolves: LE-13883
Change-Id: I4a8ff30606a4c49a42cc5271db0721a843004a67
commits.subject: Fire POLLIN event for FIFO corner case

comments.message: Shouldn't the signal have already been sent before this point?  I.e. when a read is performed and there's still data on the queue.
As discussed, please just expand the comment to add more explanation of when this case is hit.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix opening the wrong pipe device

We should open the original pipe device for the connection between
atServer and atFwdLinker, and open the data pipe device for the
connection between apps and firmware under the Data Mode. However, due
to typo and ignoring the data type size, we didn't find out the logic
error during the stress testing.

After fixing this error, we should use the right type of pipe for both
the Command Mode and Data Mode.

Resolves: LE-13925

commits.commitMessage:
Use a better way to check whether Pipe is empty

fdMonitor fires POLLIN events when the Pipe is empty, because when
fdMonitor asks Pipe to report whether it is empty or not, Pipe uses
ThreadX queue API, which turns out to be unreliable.

Now we use a semaphore to determine whether the Pipe is empty. Since
FIFO has the same issue, we also fix FIFO in the commit.

Resolves: LE-13894
Change-Id: I92b616f29a2819289f3f76fabfc075d3e5733819
commits.subject: Use a better way to check whether Pipe is empty

commits.commitMessage:
Port mbed TLS to RC76

Implement required features for mbed TLS port, and configure mbed TLS build:

 * Disable insecure algorithms and versions.
 * Turn off TLS server features.
 * Create global entropy pool and random number generator.
   * Load and save entropy seed on file system.
   * Use TrustZone random number generator as entropy source.
 * Enable thread safety features.
 * Create UNIX headers that mbed TLS socket support expects.

Resolves: LE-13730
Change-Id: I79fc68751d75bc9067771acf93def6482fe0f5a0
commits.subject: Port mbed TLS to RC76

comments.message: why are these header files included?
They are necessary to use the types from qapi_adaptor.h when it is included directly.
shouldnt we include pthread.h from frameworkadaptor?
Whoops, I forgot this file was still in the commit.  You are correct that pthread.h from up one directory should be used (it didn't exist when I started doing the mbed TLS port).

commits.commitMessage:
Decrease socket monitor thread priority

Reduce socket monitor thread priority to minimum.  This is to decrease
number of times socket monitor thread will fire when a data available
notification is waiting to be processed.

Resolves: LE-13624
Change-Id: I57a73fa66244650db5be5193d5c20b4fd5c621ad
commits.subject: Decrease socket monitor thread priority

commits.commitMessage:
Implement timegm on ThreadX

Provide an implementation for timegm on ThreadX.
Add tests to exercise cases where the input time is outside
the valid range allowed by QTI.

Resolves: LE-13666

commits.commitMessage:
Integrate Switch Mode API

We create a new custom device, Data Pipe, based on the original Pipe
deivce. The new Data Pipe device will switch between the Command Mode
and Data Mode when we open and close the device.

Since portService needs to use Data Pipe in the blocking mode, we also
fix several blocking mode issues in this commit.

Resolves: LE-13682
Change-Id: Ic07129a092001f733bddb560405daaf865fb50e1
commits.subject: Integrate Switch Mode API

comments.message: Will calling this API trigger an FD monitor each time it is called? Since this API may be called multiple times for the same le_fd_write() call, there's the potential of triggering multiple POLLIN's where the first one would only really be needed. This might be the cause of the EACCESS issue for le_fd_Read() or something similar
The queue only has one item. If we don't call fd_SignalDevice here, tx_queue_send will be blocked forever, because the fdMonitor callback never has a chance to read and pop the queue item.
If the pipe size is greater than 1 then the issue will happen. Create a bug please to address this
Can you add a little more explanation was a data pipe is vs a regular pipe

This really belongs in PortService platformAdaptor, as it is on hl78.  To unblock others I'm OK with this for now; but I think this should be reviewed/fixed before rc51 as I think there's room for optimization here.

commits.commitMessage:
Start new thread for CLI commands.

Start each CLI command in its own thread, as a regular app processes.
This allows them to bind to APIs and perform IPC as any other task.

Resolves: LE-13555
Change-Id: I2c6e8ed71088ea3a83db85aa4d9c09ce7125db19
commits.subject: Start new thread for CLI commands.

Compiling avcService on ThreadX

Implement inet_ntoa, le16toh, le32toh and IN6_IS_ADDR_V4MAPPED.

Resolves: LE-13729 LE-13737

comments.message: Shouldn't this go in qapi_netdb.h.  Also don't need #ifndef.
This was removed on purpose as we now accept non-zero, we just ignore it.
Should this go next to AI_NUMERICHOST?  Also, should it have a different value than AI_NUMERICHOST?

variable.

comments.message: This needs to be removed because it causes unintended context switches whenever this is called
We need it to build switch out the code if it doesn't exist. Without this it breaks the hl78 build
This is still needed, please do not remove.

Anytime LE_TEST_INFO is called can cause an unintended context switch. I removed this because it caused the thread test to act weird. I know if we remove it then we won't get output if a thread crashes after it but I think that under normal circumstances, it shouldn't change anything. I can still keep it if you think that it's for the best.

I think it's better to leave it.  Yes, it causes extra context switching, but case of crashing during a test is not as uncommon as I'd like, so it's nice to get a closer link to where test actually crashed.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix memory leak for ThreadCtx memory pool.

Memory allocation for thread context pool was failing as the memory was
not being released. This patch covers fix for storing the context for
thread so that it can be released later.

Also, use le_mem_Alloc() instead of le_mem_AssertAlloc() for thread
memory pools so that the memory pool is expanded as needed.

Resolves: LE-13623
Change-Id: Id7494f1bc69b01a571096f835de5179b65a97641
commits.subject: Fix memory leak for ThreadCtx memory pool.

comments.message:
seeing a build failure here after the newest merge, looking into why

- In the meanwhile I have a added a temp workaround so we can get this building on the farm.
Some new features got pushed into legato recently that needed to be absorbed, now that I have done that I am no longer seeing this failure.

Hmm..?  If the purpose is to remove logging for space considerations, better to set static log level in kconfig configuration.  If it doesn't compile, better to change definition of _LE_LOG_QFLOG_INT() instead.

This code causes a compile failure. So the quickest solution is to define these out.
I think debugging the compile issue is outside the module team's scope.

Generally, the module team would not be making any Legato changes. At least not without prior consent. :)

Can you share the compiler error you are seeing with me?  I don't have a 9x05 environment set up.  According to Qualcomm doc QAPI should be identical between 9X05, 9X06 and 9X07, and I assume compiler is the same (or at least similar), so I'm trying to understand why a change is needed here.  Maybe add a comment to the source.

E.g. is it possible to put #ifdef SWI_PLATFORM_9X05 around _LE_LOG_QFLOG() and/or _LE_LOG_QFLOG_INT() instead?  I'd like to keep platform dependencies as small as possible and at as low a layer as possible so higher level code can be the same.

commits.commitMessage:
Add bsd sys/time.h to ThreadX platform adaptor

The BSD sys/time.h provides useful functions for handling
POSIX timespecs such as add/subtract, etc.

Resolves: LE-13755
Change-Id: I2ac0c364319f64bc4fda4d3e6e2a7478532004e5

commits.commitMessage:
Implement getaddrinfo() for ThreadX

Legato code uses getaddrinfo() to perform DNS lookup.  Implement
this using the Qualcomm qapi_Net_DNSc_ apis.

Resolves: LE-13056
Change-Id: Ic2f75db5559e429d26685c979a762eb17ca8d5bc
commits.subject: Implement getaddrinfo() for ThreadX

comments.message: I think MAX_FILE_DESCRIPTORS above be under this menu, too.
Might it not be reasonable to assert if it is non-zero?
No, passing in non-zero is legitimate, and in fact Legato code passes in non-zero values.  But it for IP it doesn't provide any additional info other than what's in the type, so can be ignored.
Always returning the IPv4 status isn't random, says Capt. Pedantic :).

> Random: 1. Made, done, or happening without method [...]

Source: Oxford English Dictionary

There is no method behind picking ip4 over ip6 status to return.
This is on purpose to separate legato includes from QTI includes.

commits.commitMessage:
Add support to port le_pa

Add few macros and timegm() stub for building le_pa.

Resolves: LE-13688
Change-Id: Ic5a3ca7cc6ae9496f4f471d51000d86d53316b85

commits.commitMessage:
Implement localtime_r and tzset

Implement tzset by maintaining a file in the EFS containing
timezone/DST offset to be read. tzset will read and cache the
file contents to be read by localtime_r.

Resolves: LE-13375
Change-Id: I03ae2e320413743101da8a15ff372fd203bacda7
commits.subject: Implement localtime_r and tzset

comments.message: There is LE_MUTEX_DECLARE_REF() which provides mutex declaration, lock and unlock functions. Maybe you can use that instead.
This api is provided at a lower layer than legato so I think it's probably better to not use le_mutex for this.
It seems the file TIME_ZONE_FILE is assumed to be existed before calling tzset(), is it created anywhere when initialization?
Yes it expects the file to be written by a service in legato. I've now added access check before attempting to open the file.
qapi_FS_Close(fd) is not needed if open is failed, so maybe it is better to move these code to between line 237 and 238,
Use #define instead of a magic number.
Don't need to check existence separately; just open.
If qapi_FS_Read takes a uint32 (instead of a uint32_t), I think you should just us a uint32 instead.
Should also fail if sizeof(tzFileStr) == readBytes -- i.e. the file is larger than you expect.

This doesn't seem to be a correct (or at least not a portable) usage of strtok_r.  savePtr should be different than str, and str should be NULL on subsequent calls.

You may also want to consider using sscanf() or strchr() instead of strtok(), as they are (in my opinion) easier to use and don't modify the string being parsed.

And I'm curious why you chose a text format instead of a binary format?  It's not necessarily wrong, but a binary format would avoid parsing entirely.
I took your suggestion and used binary format instead

This doesn't look correct.  It calculates according to if you're currently in DST, not if the time being calculated is in DST.  It also does not automatically adjust when you enter/leave DST.  If you're going to do that, it can just be rolled into the timezone_offset.
Based on the discussion we had today, I'll be leaving this as is.
Brackets to clarify order of operations.
If this structure is only used internally, it is better to keep it inside, not exposing it in .h file.

Ditto. In this patch, this function seems only used for test, if so, may need to move to test file. However, it should also be called for the timezone initialization in the very beginning before tzset(), didn't see such code in this patch. Thus, if I missed something and it should be exposed, ignfore this comment.
This function will be called later by the legato layer once QMI services are ready so I need to keep this public.
Need to check if readBytes != TIME_ZONE_FILE_MAX_SIZE, since according to qapi doc, qapi_FS_Read is permitted to read fewer bytes than desired.
Should not or no need to close if open failed.

Maybe we have to check the status of qapi_FS_Close. If close failed but the previous qapi_FS_Write was successful, do we consider this case as a successful call to set_timezonefile?  This may also affect following calls to this function and tzset(). Although this possiblity is very low.
Sorry, will not affect following calls. Just status.
What prevents us from doing this test in legato/framework/test instead?  It would be nice to run this kind of test on Linux as well to make sure Linux & ThreadX have the same behaviour.

There may be some differences from linux:
- time is lower bound to Jan 6, 1980 on TX which is different from Linux epoch time
- set_timezonefile is TX specific

commits.commitMessage:
Fix building legato against testFrameworkAdaptor.sdef

Fixed socketComponent/test.c to pass in int32_t instead of
pointer to int when calling getsockopt.

Resolves: LE-13589
Change-Id: Ib8e29870a2f98db0f432011a134dd5fbf3a2e1fc
commits.subject: Fix building legato against testFrameworkAdaptor.sdef

comments.message: I think the issue is the prototype of getsockopt is not compatible with the standard one, so maybe change the getsockopt function, since other places may call this function in a standard way(with &).
I can add a comment but I'll probably just create a ticket to track this issue; running test_Socket requires some setup to be done before running the test.
I think this should be left in.  Sure running socket tests requires some setup, but that's expected.
Same comment as before -- please leave this in.

commits.commitMessage:
Extend le_atomic.h API's

Added ThreadX implementation for GCC primitives not available
	- __atomic_or_fetch()
	- __atomic_and_fetch()
	- __atomic_add_fetch()
	- __atomic_sub_fetch()
	- __sync_bool_compare_and_swap()

Relates: LE-13492
Resolves: LE-13496
Change-Id: I574a8bd9abe3a9571ad79c3914280221c3fc9b0c
commits.subject: Extend le_atomic.h API's

comments.message: Needs DMB before as well if it's sync.  With __atomic (If I understand correctly), we need DMB before if it's RELEASE, and DMB after if it's ACQUIRE.
I think volatile here is not actually needed.
Doing two atomic operations in a row isn't atomic.  I would just implement for uint32.
Add DMB before lock as well?

You need to have the result returned directly from the function itself.  See comment on the function -- I think to properly implement this function you need to return the value stored; not the value at some point later.
The old method of hard coding each was better.  This kind of code re-use is great in theory, but atomics should be tight and fast.  Could do a macro I suppose.
