commits.commitMessage:
Fix the Bug of insufficient thread keys

Thread tls functions are ported from and aligned with HL78 where
the pthread_key_delete() is not provided. Test cases are also
added.

Resolves: LE-13575
Change-Id: I9282316f9abc0f03f028557011435f1d46f74248
commits.subject: Fix the Bug of insufficient thread keys

comments.message: Not 100% but having the description a line after the @return may cause the doxygen to look off. Probably better to put it in line with the @return
How can the key be invalid if it hasn't been created yet? Might want to just update this to say that it will return EINVAL if passed a null pointer or the destructor is not NULL
Consult to Andrew, it was not used in HL78, and not implemented in HL78 as well, so just ported the code from HL78 and aligned with it.
Please describe how your thread local storage is implemented here

Use a memory pool, do no dynamically allocate memory

The memory pool have a size of the max number of threads multiplied by the max number of keys. The value that's stored using the qurt tls API should point to the offset within the table for that thread. The key will will be used as an offset within the table which will be added to the TLS stored address

Yes, mempool is a better idea, I was wondering is it possible that the tls function are used before mempool is initialized. The key value here will not used as an offset, this implementation actually only uses one qurt key for the entire process.
If it's using only one qurt key, and the value is the same regardless of the thread, why use QuRT's thread local storage?
This should be compared to the pthread_tls_key_count because you could get a key before it is set

I may be misunderstanding this but I think the test is missing the point of thread local storage.

What you should prove is that by setting the same key to something in multiple threads will store it only for that thread.

Say if Thread 1 stores a '35' in key '1' and Thread 2 stores a '47' in key '1' too, Thread 1 should read '35' when it gets the value from key '1' and Thread 2 will get a '47' when it does the same.

That's the normal way, but the HL78 implemented it in a different way which I think is fine: it always generates a unique key for any thread when call to pthread_key_create(). POSIX does not require that same keys have to be available for different threads. Will add comment to briefly explain the idea in thread_posix.c.

If you look at pthread_cleanup_push() and pthread_cleanup_pop(), that's how it works.

Also, POSIX does require the same key available for different threads. Otherwise it's no different than having each thread allocate it's own memory.
If the CleanupKey is now using your new implementation make sure that test_TheadCleanup passes
Can you call this as part of pthread_create()? You should also release the memory when the thread's are destroyed otherwise you'll introduce a memory leak
You are right, it has memory leaking issue.
Can you put it pthread_join's rather than sleeps? They do the same thing right now anyways

This still doesn't test that different threads store different values for the same key. You're setting and getting the key immediately so even if your threads overwrote each other for the same key, this would pass.

What I want to see is that you have 1 thread store a value to a key and wait on another thread to do the same for the same key value. Once both threads have been written to (you can coordinate this using semaphores), read the same tls key in each thread and make sure that it's the same value you wrote to earlier in the thread.
This needs to be done as a destructor on the qurt tls entry, otherwise you will still have a leak in the case where we return from the thread function instead of calling pthread_exit().
Need a destructor for this to avoid memory leak (see other comment).
This will only be called once and will last for as long as the device is powered
Destructor is for the thread local data, so is called to destroy TLS data when a thread exits.
Can you fix this up as well to also have a destructor while you're at it?  I missed this in the initial review of the patch that made this change.
Is that necessary? This should only be called once
can make this void**, then eliminate the cast below.
This is OK, but can we increment pthread_tls_key_count atomically and eliminate the lock instead?
Is this cast required?  void * -> another pointer type usually does not require a cast in C.
This one's required because it's converting from a const to a non-const. Leaving the const as a parameter so it's closer to the POSIX signature
I'd just make this PTHREAD_NUM_TLS_POINTERS.  Elements past pthread_tls_key_count are set to 0, and you eliminate risks about non-atomic operations.
Same comment as above.  Is this cast required?
Same treatment for cleanup?  At the moment I think you don't execute the cleanup functions if you return from the thread function.  Maybe just create a bug for this and handle later.
Instead just call ReleaseThreadResources here?  Not sure why you need to push, just to pop afterwards.

I essentially did this to follow PThreadStartRoutine() in thread.c. By pushing ReleaseThreadResources() to the cleanup handler stack, we won't need explicitly call it in __wrap_pthread_exit(). Let me know if you want me to replace this with a call to ReleaseThreadResources() here and in __wrap_pthread_exit()
I think it's probably better to call explicitly, in case pthread_cleanup_pop() is called somewhere else.  Using pthread_cleanup_push() to release TLS would cause unexpected behaviour in that case.
Need to call ReleaseThreadResources here as well?
See the above comment. Will be the last thing on the stack so it will be called here
You still also need to call pthread_cleanup_pop(1) here to execute any cleanup functions the user has pushed.

There won't be any cleanup handlers left even if a user has pushed some once it returns here. There is also no way someone can accidentally forget to add a matching pthread_cleanup_pop() to a pthread_cleanup_push() as it won't compile in that case.

If someone terminates a thread by returning in between a pthread_cleanup_push()/pop() pair, which you shouldn't do and isn't specified as one of the conditions to run a cleanup handler here http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/pthread_cleanup_push.3.html, calling pthread_cleanup_pop() would cause you to reference a structure that was allocated on the stack and is no longer there.

I'll add an assert here to make sure no one returns from a pthread in between a pthread_cleanup_push/pop pair.

commits.commitMessage:
Implement ThreadX-based pipe custom device

Originally we use UNIX socket for bi-direction communication between the
AT service and atFwdLinker. However, we don't have UNIX socket on the
ThreadX platform, so we need to implement a pipe custom device for the
duplex communication.

Resolves: LE-13561 LE-13498
Change-Id: I962a5b3aacae30460ff7cba0c7cf775cb3a56e1d
commits.subject: Implement ThreadX-based pipe custom device

comments.message: Should just be "Pipes" (only initial letter is capitalized).  FIFO is an acronym, pipe is not.  Ditto elsewhere.
I think this can be smaller -- what's the max AT command size?  1500 is chosen for FIFO because it's Ethernet MTU (if I remember correctly).

The max size of a single response is defined by LE_ATDEFS_RESPONSE_MAX_BYTES, which is 513. Now Shristi and I also agree that the max size of the AT command string will change from 1024 to 513. So I will define the default size to 513.
Could you rename this to atFwdLinker?
Or -- thinking about the Linux case -- have le_fd_OpenPipe(pathname, flags, PIPE_CLIENT (or PIPE_SERVER)) which combines mkPipe & open, but passes flags explicitly.

I'd round up a bit -- at least to something divisible by 4 (516?).  The linker will likely reserve the space for you anyway.

But that's aesthetic, not really critical.

commits.commitMessage:
Add the missing constant required by fcntl()

When we tried to call le_fd_Fcntl to check if the specified file
descriptor is valid, we found that the F_GETFD constant is missing. Add
this constant so we can port the AT service to ThreadX.

Resolves: LE-13498
Change-Id: If2931038b76fb2eaae94caec4356d9935732a310
commits.subject: Add the missing constant required by fcntl()

comments.message: Don't you need to do an implementation, not just define this constant?

commits.commitMessage:
Reset hl76 after test

To align better with other platforms, reset hl76 after the test,
instead of before.  Also modify wait times and reset detection
to be more reliable.

Resolves: LE-13467
Change-Id: I7f4ef7535962174be68d2f316e8a904d2030a4ee
commits.subject: Reset hl76 after test

comments.message: Why remove the optimization for the skipped test cases? Is it because it will cause some side-effect?
I'm moving reset to after the test is run (see https://gerrit.legato/c/Legato/+/51367/1/conftest.py#618), so I think we will still not be resetting if the test is skipped.  I need to 2x check though.

The reason I'm doing this change is I was failures of test after test_Fd, which seemed to be tied to the chip not actually getting reset in some cases.  So I'm modifying the code to work more like hl78 in hopes it gets rid of this issue.
If we execute 'reset' after a test case, it means that we are not sure the state when we run the first test case. We can only guarantee by manually reset the machine before running pytest.

To clarify on this:  I think it's not a problem in practice as we should always be flashing the device immediately before running tests, so the device will be in clean reset.  But, if we decide we need to alter so the device is reset before running the test, it should be changed in legato/conftest.py so all devices get the new behaviour as well.
As long as we know what should be done before running pytest, it's ok to reset the device after running a test. For example, LeTP can reset the device before running pytest.

commits.commitMessage:
Implement le_log filter level API for TX

Referenced Linux log filter level implementation
and added SetFilterLevel and GetFilterLevel in order to
provide ability to configure filter levels during runtime.
Fixed LE_DUMP compilation errors.

Resolves: LE-13070
Change-Id: Ic3c3d7617df11de00fe2fb89368cc334fdd1a243
commits.subject: Implement le_log filter level API for TX

comments.message: Should we check the level value to make sure it's within the allowed level value before assigning the value to LE_LOG_LEVEL_SET_FILTER? Or is the value already validated somewhere else?
May need to be const uint8_t*, I have found a compilation error in modemService code which try to call LE_DUMP with a const unit8_t* parameter.
Did you add a space to make it 4 spaces? The code below needs to be shifted by a space as well in that case. It looks off by 1.
I think this line was just off by one, fixed

Will it make sense if we create a macro for 8 and use the macro in line 97, 102, and 103 instead of using hard-coded 8? In case we need to use a different value in the future, we just change the number in the macro definition?
Something like:
#define MAX_LOG_BYTES 8
Won't this fit in the above line and still be within the max chars allowed in a line?
I just wanted to align it to 8 bytes, I've moved this to the same line now.
Can we also use sizeof(dumpBufUnaligned) here?
Add = LE_LOG_LEVEL_STATIC_FILTER, then you can avoid the init in fa_log_Init().
This test doesn't have any test cases.  I would not check this in.

commits.commitMessage:
Do not store return status if NULL

pthread_join() is documented as accepting NULL for return status
location, in which case the result status of the thread should
not be stored.  Modify pthread_join() workaround to follow this
behaviour.

Resolves: LE-13467
Change-Id: I31ddfa812d2e5248d5d34371901d6ca18f78982a
commits.subject: Do not store return status if NULL

commits.commitMessage:
Sleep for 2 ms when logging test results

Qualcomm QCLI will sometimes drop log messages if too much output
is sent to the CLI.  According to Qualcomm it takes 2 ms to send
a line of output, so waiting for this length of time should prevent
dropped messages.

Resolves: LE-13446
Change-Id: I107c53a010994181c81eef02b92954f185fb121b
commits.subject: Sleep for 2 ms when logging test results

commits.commitMessage:
Implement socket monitoring

Sockets are added to a set which is monitored by a central "select
thread."  When one or more are signalled, events are then dispatched
back to the event loops of the corresponding threads.

Currently there is no way to break out of the select call on-demand
(see LE-13444), so the timeout for the select must be used to check for
updates to the socket set periodically.

Relates: LE-13444
Resolves: LE-13066
Change-Id: Iea339f8c6015dfb2aa08f4f758b5b8dae7b7f250
commits.subject: Implement socket monitoring

comments.message: If my understanding's correct, if there's a socket that has just started to be monitored and it's signalled, it'll have to wait for another socket to be signalled or a timeout. Is this latency okay?
It's temporary until we get a solution from Qualcomm which allows us to trigger select() early.
Should this be a higher priority thread than normal apps?
Dunno.  Suggest leaving as-is and adjusting the priority if we run into issues.
Add a LE_ASSERT if it's full
Linked lists can't be full (le_sls_Queue() doesn't even have a return).

Could we add this to qapi_adaptor.h like the other error code conversion functions? I think this might come in handy again

comments.message: Check strrchr has not returned NULL?

Since the line 276 added a '/' to the string, and line 284 to 287 will not remove this added '/' (this if tries to remove '/' from iterEntry.file_Path), so if the code can reach here, there will be a '/' in the string. Is there any situation I missed?

commits.subject: Implements pthread_cond variables

comments.message: Moved this to KConfig and added an explanation there
Need some comments for arguments, the same for bellows.
I think a better way is to avoid using _pthread_cond functions, and directly define these them pthread_cond function, and no need to #define these macros here.
I've already tried doing this but because these functions are already defined in apps_proc, there'd be two definitions for the same function causing a compilation error
this change was corrected and merged.
This was experimentally determined as it doesn't seem to be 100 ticks per second
The macro LE_MUTEX_DECLARE_REF seems also declares MutexRef inside of it, please check /legato/framework/include/le_mutex.h.
Better to name them without underscore, and remove macros in qapi_adaptor.h. The same to other functions in this file.
This one's fine but the one below it is wrong
According to your macro MAX_THREADS_WAIT_PER_COND_VAR_CNT, which has value 4, but this graph shows 5.
The macro MAX_THREADS_WAIT_PER_COND_VAR_CNT is variable based on KConfig but I can change it to 4
Maybe also need NULL check and range check for cond.

This is racy.

E.g. A is signalling cond variable; B and C are waiting on the same cond variable with a timeout, B has higher priority.  

A: Signal cond variable.  Gets to Unlock() on line 184.
B: Wake (higher priority; timeout expires), returns ETIMEDOUT
A: Resumes from this point, signals B to wake.

At this point B has already woken, so C should wake.  But that won't happen because A decided B should wake.

There are similar races which can occur for other reasons B wakes before getting signaled by this thread (e.g. a second thread signals the same condition).
I moved the lock to just before the function returns and I think that will solve the problem.

You can avoid the loop:

    flags_to_set = ((1 << MAX_THREADS_WAIT_PER_COND_VAR) - 1) << cond_idx;
Unlock then wait introduces a race -- another thread could lock the mutex, signal, and unlock before tx_event_flags_get() is called, resulting in the signal getting lost.

I'll have to test this but I don't think this scenario would result in the signal getting lost. The variables that keep track of which thread is waiting on which flag is guarded by a different mutex, so if a higher-priority thread was preempted as soon as the mutex on line 335 is unlocked, it will go through and set the flag that the wait thread is about to wait on. When control returns to the thread that was interrupted, it will hit line 338 and just not wait as the bit it's waiting on is already set.

commits.commitMessage:
Port le_fs API to ThreadX

Implement required POSIX functions to support le_fs API.
read/write are implemented inside fs.c in order to
prevent naming conflicts with BSD sockets.

Resolves: LE-13069
Change-Id: If0b007d12ccaec5b60594ed7b603228546f8658b
commits.subject: Port le_fs API to ThreadX

comments.message: the macro NOT_IMPLEMENTED may be better.
Test test whether lseek() is working properly,can we read several bytes and test these bytes are correct after calling lseek().
this app is already changed to start manually, so no need to comment it.
This needs brackets to avoid unexpected issues when the macro is expanded.
Can't use the name close, this will conflict with BSD socket implementation.
Can't use the name read, as this will conflict with BSD socket implementation.
Can't use the name write, as this will conflict with the BSD socket implementation.
Sorry I thought I removed these, fixed.

Should be moved as were read()/write()/close().  Ditto with lseek() below.  These are not a usable API by themselves, so it doesn't make sense to expose them with the POSIX name if read/write/close cannot be exposed.
If this isn't needed, it should just be removed.
Should be based on the #define from Qualcomm sources.
qapiOpen to match other functions?  Or just use qapi_ function directly (see comment below).

I would just call the QAPI function directly here -- I don't think you gain anything from the wrapper.  It's not portable anyway, and by using a wrapper a bunch of unnecessary translation and error handling gets pulled in (e.g. errno translation isn't necessary as setting errno is not part of the interface of this function; this handling of errno == EINTR isn't necessary as the Qualcomm function cannot set errno to EINTR).
Remove comment as well if typedef is removed.

commits.commitMessage:
Port POSIX clock functions to ThreadX

Implement gmtime,gmtime_r,gettimeofday, also
had to implement time() as it was crashing the device
when called. localtime/localtime_r currently returns
the same results as gmtime/gmtime_r as timezones
are not implemented.

Change-Id: I35d9acebe6befd3beaa2a536fafad59ecdf9029c
Resolves: LE-13057
commits.subject: Port POSIX clock functions to ThreadX

comments.message: Please add a comment describing why you have to call setlocale() for the clock functions to work.
The default stack size is set to 4K, this line is no longer needed.
this argument has no comment while others have.
may need to break into two lines.

Should not have #if 0 code checked in.  Is clock_settime() required for Legato services?  If so we need to work on a resolution for this issue.  If not can we eliminate this function entirely?  It's better to see errors as soon as possible, so in general a compiler error is better than a runtime error if there's no reasonable implementation of the function on a platform.
I will stub this function out to return EPERM (like uLegato) since it's currently only being called by le_clk_SetUTCDateTimeString which  is only enabled by LE_CONFIG_LINUX.
Is this stub needed?  Or can it be eliminated until timezones are implemented?

It's still being called by le_clk_ConvertToLocalTimeString.
I could have stubbed this out with a macro instead or just comment out the call in le_clk.
Oh, if it's used that's OK.
What is the reason for implementing this function?  It's not required by Legato and is broken in a multi-threaded environment.  Ditto for localtime.
Why lock/unlock here?  This is broken if called in a multi-threaded environment anyway.
The return value needs to be multiplied by 1000000 to convert the remainder (in ms) to ns.

commits.commitMessage:
Port le_pathIter component

Copy the pathIter implementation from legato/framework/liblegato/linux
and modify the corresponding tests in legato/apps/test/framework.

The trickiest part is to remember calling pathIter_init() in
InitLegatoFramework() in microSupervisor.c, or you won't be able to use
the memory pool.

Resolves: LE-13076
Change-Id: Id41e6cf8878ed8dd61c6aa458236c29c29611a49
commits.subject: Port le_pathIter component

comments.message: Will remove in the next patch. Since I copy this file from legato/framework/liblegato/linux, that file has the same issue. Will fix that file when it is covered by a ticket.
If this is copied from legato/framework/liblegato/linux, can you share the implementation instead of copying/pasting?

I was told that I should not reference implementation under framework/liblegato/linux in framework/liblegato/ninja-generator, and platform-dependent implementation should be put in frameworkAdaptor. Since pathIter.c is under framework/liblegato/linux, I was told that the ThreadX implementation should be in frameworkAdaptor. I am confused about what the "share implementation" means.

You should not directly include something in framework/liblegato/linux in ThreadX, but maybe this file could be moved to another location where it could be shared between the two.  Or create a posixPathIter.c (or similar) with an internal API, then both framework/liblegato/linux/pathIter.c and frameworkAdaptor/pathIter.c would call this internal API, but the internal API functions would not conflict with (for example) the hl78 implementation of le_pathIter.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

As an initial point, this patch should be split into 3:

- One which implements LE-13211
- One which implements LE-13063
- One which implements LE-13055 (some changes for socket wrappers are included in this patch, despite not being mentioned in the patch notes).

the current patch combines multiple mostly unrelated fixes, which makes it hard to review.

The method used here for translating error codes is problematic.  By including fs_errno.h, errno.h and qapi_socket.h, which have conflicting definitions of some error codes, in legato.h there's too much room for error and confusion.  There's a list of #defines which have to match Qualcomm-provided code exactly, making it fragile when new versions of Qualcomm code are released.

Instead I suggest:

- Create fa_errno_int.h which defines LE_<error_code> error codes.  E.g. LE_EPIPE
- In socket translation layer file, #include "qapi_socket.h" and "fa_errno_int.h", but _not_ "legato.h".  Implement SkErrToPosixErr in this file.  Follow this same approach for any other translation layer with conflicting error code definitions.
- Create fa_errno.h included from legato.h which #defines LE_<error_code> to <error_code>.  E.g. #define EPIPE LE_EPIPE, etc.

Add few string functions

Add functions strdup(), strtok_r(), and strerror_r(), together
with test code.

Resolves: LE-13063
Change-Id: I967663d8872164cbdf5b494861a38b1292475e08
commits.subject: Add few string functions

comments.message: Why is it necessary to redefine these?  If you are already doing a translation from qualcomm error codes to errno, can't you just leave these as the value defined in errno.h?

the errno.h is a system header file, which only contains 6 macros (EDOM, ERANGE, EILSEQ, ESIGNUM, EINVAL, and ENOMEM). The qapi_socket.h file provides most of the POSIX errnos, but some of them conflict with errnos defined in errno.h. So undef and define those conflicted macros are necessary for implementing the function strerror_r().
Where does SK_ENOBUFS come from?  These definitions seem unnecessary to me -- can't you just use ENOBUFS?
I would not use "new" as it is a keyword in c++ and will confuse syntax highlighters (as it does here).
len + 1 to get the terminating NULL?
len has already included the NULL, does not need +1. see line 33.

Should this instead be 

    #if EINVAL != LE_EINVAL
        #error EINVAL does not match Legato definition in LE_EINVAL
    #endif

etc.?  I think these definitions should match, correct?

EINVAL != LE_EINVAL will be always true here, since the EINVAL from arm c lib "errno.h" is 5 and LE_EINVAL from "fa_errno_int.h" is a different value (i.e., 2000). Since these three macros are defined in current c lib file "errno.h", lines 54 to 64 are actually not effective.
Default stack size has been increased to 4K, so I think this is not needed anymore.
This first line can be removed I think?

Please document the function arguments inline unless it is a function-like macro.
Applies to the rest of this file too
Please document the function arguments inline for this function and the rest of the file as well
do we want to null check errBuf here?
isn't this change covered by another ticket?

I don't understand this comment.  If Qualcomm is defining this value, then why do you define this below?  If Qualcomm is not defining this value, you don't need to undef here.  Anyway, undef'ing here is likely to create issues if/when we test errno after a C standard library function which sets errno.

ERANGE is #defined in <errno.h> with a value that conflicts with the value of ETIMEDOUT in "qapi_socket.h". This introduces the ambiguity to strerror_r(). Is it possible to avoid this conflict by using _AEABI_PORTABILITY_LEVEL?
This should be called test_<something>.adef and included in testFrameworkAdaptor.sdef to ease future integration with py.test.
Should put spaces around here.  As it stands the error string will be "Operation timed out.orParameter out of range.".
Add start: manual to this file.

commits.commitMessage:
Implement le_rtosCli for ThreadX

Add an implementation of the le_rtosCli for ThreadX.  This allows
commands to be added to a system via the commands: section in a
.sdef.

Resolves: LE-13251
Change-Id: I51cf8341654edbcbd8d09d5cc7664a2978f6025b
commits.subject: Implement le_rtosCli for ThreadX

comments.message: This macro does not seem to be used, so I will remove it.

le_rtosCli.h indirectly #includes qcli_socket.h, which brings some POSIX macros from Qualcomm. If this le_rtosCli.h is #included here, then it will be included in legato.h, makes the Qualcomm POSIX macros global. Can it be placed to a different place since it was only used in rtosSystemGenerator.cpp.
Do you mean qapi_socket?  I think this is OK -- as long as we're careful to just include the qapi version of these macros there should be no conflict.

Yes, it's qapi_socket.h, sorry for the typo. By exposing this file, I think there are two possible issues:
(1) Possible conflict after porting some other APIs in the future. 
(2) The C lib header errno.h #included in legato.h has #defined several macros that have conflict values with few macros in qapi_socket.h, this brings ambiguities to implement strerror_r() function for LE-13063.

For (1), I am satisfied with your solution. For (2), I think we need to find a solution first before merging this code patch.
the status here is a qapi errno, may not be translated by le_threadx_qurt2errno() which translates qurt errno.

commits.commitMessage:
Modify fifo and file descriptors to be ran on ThreadX and QuRT

Modify directly ported code to be ran using QuRT API's and ThreadX
queues. Also addressed bug where priority level's are reversed

Resolves: LE-13065 LE-13199 LE-13262
Change-Id: I4275d20ffebc372dd7ca4ae404515e635f40d0ab
commits.subject: Modify fifo and file descriptors to be ran on ThreadX and QuRT

comments.message: This should be set in a KConfig entry, not a direct #define.  See http://cgit.legato/Legato/frameworkAdaptor/hl78-mcu.git/tree/KConfig for an example.
Could block even if the flag is set to NON_BLOCK so I changed this in the implementation to the right
These should all come from KConfig.
This is required as the compiler doesn't allow anonymous unions
There isn't a queue peek like there is one in FreeRTOS but we can look at what's next to be read in threadX which is almost the same as peeking
Why was setting the status here removed?  This needs to remain, although there should be a NULL check added.

Seems this header is common among Altair & ThreadX.
Should this be RTOS-specific ?

The same applies to other header files.

Add app CLI tool to ThreadX

microSupervisor in a init function.

manually start apps through CLI.

Resolves: LE-13098

commits.subject: Add app CLI tool to ThreadX

comments.message: Please wrap this line to no more than 100 characters.
Why?  Please elaborate in the comment.
Replace this with the contents from above.
This function (the one that is exported and referenced in legato.scons) should be renamed to le_tools_RegisterCmds.
Why are the changes in this file needed for this patch?

Actually, this change is for LE-13099, just committed with LE-13098 and forgot to add LE-13099. I can revise the commit message to add LE-13099 to the Resolves line, or do shall I make a new commit for LE-13099?

Yes, if possible, please split into a separate patch.  Although I think this is the wrong approach to resolve LE-13099, and is not what I had contemplated for that ticket.  Instead I was considering an approach more along the lines of what was in my [WIP] patch where only LE_TEST output is put to CLI, and other log output is still written to QXDM.

So, if LE_TEST implementation does not depend on printf(), and the log output goes to QXDM, then yes, we do not need the change in this file. This also related to the change in KConfig. And, both changes were actually suggested by Andrew, I think we need to get an agreement on this.
This implementation should be split into a separate file.
Should also log to QXDM (as discussed previously).
log to both CLI and QXDM would be another code change for ticket: LE-13099
Suggest adding \r\n to end of putcBuff first -- will save a call to PAL_Console_Write.
Why is it necessary to create a thread to perform this registration?  Please add a comment on this.

This seems like a bad name, as it is not just initializing the tools, but also all of Legato.

Also this is the wrong spot to put this, as it is not tools specific, but related to all of Legato.
Should not be added to liblegato.
printf_helper should be moved to liblegato directory.
Should this be -2?  One for \r, one for \n.
Not necessary, compiler reports some warnings without the casts.
If compiler reports warnings without them, that's an OK reason.

commits.commitMessage:
Create simple pthread implementation on Qualcomm

This creates a few simple POSIX-compatible wrappers on Qualcomm APIs.
Note this does not provide full POSIX compatibility, but only the
functionality required for this stage of Legato.

Resolves: LE-13033
Change-Id: I8bc412ab67caf968ff7cf034426c8fe439d493df
commits.subject: Create simple pthread implementation on Qualcomm

comments.message: Do we need these constants if thread cancellation is not supported at all on ThreadX (meaning it is always disabled, right)?
Yes.  Some code assumes they are present.

Thread cancellation only takes effect at "cancellation points".  Implementing cancellation points requires support all over the code, making implementing this feature correctly complex.  On top of that thread cancellation is bug prone as most developers (myself included) aren't familiar with which functions are cancellation points and which are not, making it easy to leak resources if a function which is a cancellation point is called between acquiring and releasing a resource.

The better way to implement this is to send a message to the thread (e.g. through queuing a function to the thread's event loop, setting a semaphore, etc.), which instructs the thread to exit.
why need waiters? is not the max(-value,0) meaning the number of waiters?
I don't understand what you're trying to say here.
does variable waiters mean the number of threads waiting for the resource and the variable value denote the number of resource available? if yes, then I think the waiters is redundant to value.
After checking the official pthread documents, the value needs to be non-negative and I agree that the waiters as a counter for waiting threads needs to be kept.

Actually not true.  Per POSIX: "[if sem is locked, the value] shall either be set to zero or to a negative number whose absolute value represents the number of processes waiting for the semaphore".  Linux implementation is zero, this implementation use a negative value.
improper alignment of //, the same below

If my understanding is correct: the previous condition seems good. for the alternative one (i.e., sem->value > 0 && sem->waiters), you don't have to check the sem->value, "sem->waiters" just works fine since ever time a thread unlocks a semaphore and there is at least one thread waiting, you should wake up one or more.
You are correct, however in this case it seems to me it must be incorrect to have "while (value < 0)" in sem_WaitCoreAndUnlock().
I can see why it might be nice to directly implement le_sem on top of ThreadX semaphores!
This if statement seems always true, which is OK but weird.
I think it's not true if sem_post() is called after sem_wait().  I don't necessarily agree with this way of checking if sem_post was called to wake a waiter, but it seems to work.
Completely agree -- but I suggest fixing this as a bug.  Current implementation works well enough for what we're using it for.
The thread cleanup could be implemented using just the stack, which would eliminate the need for the CleanupPool.  That was the approach taken on the HL78 MCU.
